ES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

MPLX is continually striving to make the Niles LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote system safety, MPLX actively seeks employee input on process safety improvements. All Process Safety Events (as identified in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed, and/or investigated via a root cause analysis (TapRooT) per corporate policy. The Niles Township Fire Department (primary responder) and the City of Niles Fire Department (mutual aid) are contacted regarding participation in site emergency response and/or drills. Additionally, MPLX will work cooperatively with the community to address any concerns.

Further, the Niles LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements for LP Gas. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, an Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP)/Smart Plan is in place for the Facility and response activities are coordinated with the Niles Township Fire Department (primary responder) and the City of Niles Fire Department (mutual aid).

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Niles LP Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal keeps records for all incidental and significant chemical releases inclusive of any root cause analyses and associated follow-up actions, where appropriate. There have been no accidents within the past five (5) years resulting from the release of materials resulting in consequences covered under the EPA RMP reporting requirements.  The Terminal tracks all process safety incidents per API 754.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Niles LP Terminal is identified as a non-responding facility.  As previously noted, the Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Niles Township Fire Department (primary responder), the City of Niles Fire Department (mutual aid), and Berrien County Emergency Management. An ERAP/Smart Plan is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release or fire including implementation of emergency response notification procedures.

In the event of an emergency involving the Niles (North) LP Terminal butane tank blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Niles Township Fire Department and request their assistance.

The Niles Township Fire Department participates in annual butane training sessions for this system.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

The MPLX Terminals, LLC - Niles LP Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Niles LP Terminal is an onshore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used for the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Niles, MI. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low sulfur diesel/#2 fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various petroleum-based additives.

Niles LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. MPLX believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. MPLX promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that MPLX has designed and implemented including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;
C. A five-year accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.
